questions.question: My friend helped me when I was in danger.
questions.description: Here the subordinate clause is an adverb clause because it shows the time of the action mentioned in the main clause.

questions.question: We believe in democracy though it has its shortcomings.
questions.description: Clauses introduced by the conjunction though are adverb clauses.

questions.question: My parents were happy because I won the first prize.
questions.description: Clauses introduced by because are adverb clauses.

questions.question: This is the girl who talked to me yesterday.
questions.description: An adjective clause modifies a noun in the previous clause.

questions.question: I have lost the tickets which I bought.
questions.description: An adjective clause modifies a noun in the previous clause.

questions.question: He could not answer any of the questions that I asked him.
questions.description: An adjective clause modifies a noun in the previous clause.

questions.question: Although he is very rich, he is a miser.
questions.description: Clauses beginning with although are adverb clauses.

questions.question: Everybody admits that he is a brave man.
questions.description: A noun clause acts as the object of the verb in the main clause.

questions.question: We knew that he was guilty.
questions.description: A noun clause acts as the subject or object of the verb in the main clause.

questions.question: What he told me was a lie.
questions.description: A noun clause can be the subject of the verb in the main clause.

questions.question: He gave me everything that I asked for.
Your statement that you lost the money cannot be believed.
questions.description: A noun clause can be used in apposition to a noun or pronoun.

questions.question: The jury believed that the man was guilty.
questions.description: Here the clause ‘that the man was guilty’ is the object of the verb believed. Noun clauses act as the subject or object of the verb in the main clause.

questions.question: Come when you like.
questions.description: Here the clause ‘when you like’ modifies the noun come.

questions.question: I know the girl who won the prize.
questions.description: Here the clause ‘who won the prize’ modifies the noun girl. Adjective clauses give additional information about a noun or pronoun in the main clause.

questions.question: He confessed that he was guilty.
questions.description: Here the clause ‘that he was guilty’ is the object of the verb confessed.

questions.question: I know you have great regard for him.
questions.description: Here the clause ‘you have great regard for him’ is the object of the verb know.

questions.question: Do you think that I am a fool?
questions.description: Here the clause ‘that I am a fool’ is the object of the verb think.

questions.question: Before I die I want to see Venice.
questions.description: Here the clause ‘before I die’ gives the time of the action mentioned in the main clause. Hence it is an adverb clause of time.

questions.question: The hand that rocks the cradle rules the world.
questions.description: Here the clause ‘that rocks the cradle’ modifies the noun hand.

questions.question: I know a boy whose father serves in the army.
questions.description: Here the clause ‘whose father serves in the army’ modifies the noun boy.

questions.question: I will not go until he arrives.
questions.description: Here the clause ‘until he arrives’ gives the time of the action mentioned in the main clause.

questions.question: The coffee maker that I bought for my wife is expensive.
questions.description: Here the clause that I bought for my wife modifies the noun coffee maker.

questions.question: If you give respect, you get respect.
questions.description: Here the clause 'if you give respect' expresses a condition. Hence it is an adverb clause of condition.
